Predictable, even-handed enforcement and a culture of listening build trust so debate sharpens understanding rather than silences it.
statements.728: University campuses should protect robust, even uncomfortable, debate while treating threats, harassment, and intimidation as conduct to be addressed through clear, consistently applied policies and fair procedures. Emphasizing practical stewardship—teaching civil discourse, critical thinking, restorative practices, and creating structured forums for difficult conversations—reconciles open inquiry with the responsibility to keep learning spaces safe and inclusive.
statements.398: Campuses should vigorously defend free expression as a cornerstone of civic education while enforcing clear, content-neutral rules that prevent harassment, threats, and disruptive intimidation. Consistent, transparent enforcement, fair due process, and disciplined training in civil discourse and restorative practices will turn spirited disagreement into constructive learning and preserve both liberty and community safety.
statements.110: Rooted in a lifetime of quiet civic involvement and creative practice, this perspective holds that university campuses must vigorously protect open inquiry while setting clear, narrowly tailored rules to prevent harassment and preserve the ability to learn. Transparent enforcement, restorative dialogue, and instruction in civil discourse offer practical common ground so that debate sharpens understanding without eroding dignity or safety.
